awd_titl_txt: CRII: RI: Explainable Recognition of Social Relationships from People's Linguistic Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Social relationships between people influence not only what is said but how a message is said through linguistic cues for aspects like respect, politeness, or solidarity.   These stylistic aspects not only reflect a particular social context, but can also affect how the recipient interprets the message itself.  These relationships are often multifaceted and come with different linguistic expectations.  For example, while parents, professors, and police may all choose the language of authority, in their respective interactions with children, students, and the community, their language reflects a broader set of linguistic expectations in how they relate to others.  This project aims to study social relationships and their effect on language by building new technology that recognizes the linguistic cues of relationships resulting in significant improvements in everyday interactive language technologies such as voice assistants, translation, and summarization and lead to more natural human-machine interactions by improving the ability of machines to understand social aspects of communication that cannot be obtained from the words alone.  This research will also support an interdisciplinary cohort of PhD and undergraduate students and the development of a graduate-level course on Computational Sociolinguistics with open access materials.

This CISE Research Initiation Initiative (CRII) project investigates social relationships and their impact on language by developing new algorithms, methods, and datasets, building upon sociolinguistics theory to create a new framework for studying the interplay of language and relationships in real-world social environments.  This project contains two main phases.  The first phase develops new deep learning methods to accurately infer people's relationship from linguistic cues in their conversation.  To support this effort, it also constructs a new, massive corpus of interpersonal conversations from real-world settings and from fictional settings in movies, television, and literature.  The second phase builds interpretable computational models of communication that explain how a relationship is signaled through linguistic choices in communication, while also disentangling the linguistic influences of the conversational partners' identities.  These models enable testing and extending social science theories about relationship and social organization.  Further, this project also introduces a new natural language understanding task for identifying messages that are offensive only in certain contexts, where the linguistic cues violate social norms for a relationship, helping to further improve technologies to better the public's online experiences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined how different social relationships influence the language we speak, and in turn, how our language reveals aspects of our social relationships with others. For example, if two people are close friends, can we measurably observe that closeness in their language compared with other types of social relationships? This project was cross-cutting between Computer Science and Linguistics, which led to new technical developments on how to model social relationships and language together and new theoretical developments on writing style and the influence of social networks. The project had outcomes in three themes.


First, the project advanced our understanding of how we think about writing style?how and when we choose to use certain words. Understanding what constitutes ?style? is important for being able to say what factors ultimately influence a person to use certain words. We know that some of a person?s identity influences the way they speak and write, e.g., people can signal their age or social status by using certain words (e.g, ?groovy?). This project has advanced our understanding of style by showing that a person?s writing style is influenced not just by their peers but also the specific way a person?s social network is arranged (e.g., a large, loose collection of peers vs. a tight-knit group). In addition, this project also shows, for the first time, that a person?s own unique style, while idiosyncratic, is largely self-consistent, which can help future studies disentangle the personal and social causes for why a person chooses their writing or speech.

 

The second theme focused on understanding the different ways that people relate to each other, particularly the positive ways we interact with each other. a. One result was that we develop new ways to study how people offer condolence and empathize with each other.  A second result led to a new study of prosocial (rather than antisocial) behavior online, where we found people behave prosocially in a variety of ways. For the third result in this theme, we examined social intimacy?e.g., what might distinguish the conversation of a best friend, friend, or acquaintance? In developing the first computational models of social intimacy, we showed, for example, that being able to be anonymous online allows people to side-step the norms of their normal social relationships and be more socially intimate in their conversations. One surprising outcome from our study was connecting intimacy online to the Strangers on a Train effect, where social psychologists had shown that people have the most intimate conversations with close friends and with complete strangers (like those met serendipitously on a train), but less intimate with those social relationships in between; in this project, through studying a massive social network, we found this effect persisted online, where people are most intimate with their close friends in the network and those they reach out to who are very far away.

 

For the third theme, we studied social relationships directly. Using publically-shared relationship information from a large social network, we showed that the type of relationship strongly influenced how people communicated with each other, both at a content and topic level but also in more subtle ways. For example, people in more occupational or organizational relationships (e.g., coworkers) tended to use more collectivist language such as ?we? or ?our? instead of individualistic words like ?me?. Further, we found that the type of social relationship influences which content is reshared; we demonstrate how different types of relationships are more or less likely to reshare a message on social media based on the type of content (e.g., friends vs. coworkers may reshare different types of messages from the same person). This insight is important for our understanding of what kinds of content ?go viral? and how messages spread through the social network.

 

Across all of these themes, this project generated eight papers in top computer science conferences and was presented in 12 talks at top academic venues. To support further research, this project has released open source software for use by researchers and the general public. This project also contributed to the career development of eleven students, who have since advanced to the next stages of their career in industry, graduate school, or professorships.
